text: Draft pour. Clear gold with a white head that fizzes away quickly. The aroma has lemon juice, tart fruit, a bit of straw. Medium acidity. The woody notes of the beer work well with the tartness. Medium body and medium carbonation.

Cask (gravity) @ 31th Pigs Ear Beer and Cider Festival 2014, at The Round Chapel in Hackney, London, England [ As Elgoods Coolship Lambic ].Clear medium amber orange color with a small to average, frothy - fizzy and open, fair lacing, mostly diminishin to lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate plum - apple, sweet plum - sweet apple, barnyard, funky. Flavor is moderate sweet and light acidic with a long duration, tart plum - apple, funky, sweet apple - plum, sweet malt, dry. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is flat to soft. [20141202]
Batch 4. Clear orange gold. Aroma sorta diesel, buttery, tart lemons. Tastes apricots, grapes, buttery. Gets better as it warms. Crisp sour mouthfeel.

Saw tha iphonephan had this one and had to zip out to Arlington to follow suit. Cloudy golden color, rare bubbles. Aroma has dust, light funk, summer fruit. Taste is sour lemon with decent complexity and a bit of pepper. It works.
Copper. Earth, musty, fruit, oak, sour. Dry, tart finish. Medium bodied. Nice tart dry finish. Not the most complex but a very tasty lambic.
On draft at World of Beer in Arlington. Pours a clear copper with a quickly fading off white head. Musty aroma. Flavors of tart apple. Tart finish.
Some grapefruit and some peel. Passionfruit. Pours hazy golden without head or lacing. Tangy finish. Low carbonation. Tap at Deep Ellum.

bottle at sourfest
hazy dark gold. a little young with some butterscotch caramelisation, quite sharp slightly acetic tartness with the beginnings of interesting bret development, earthy, dry, cellars. full bodied and moderate carbonation...a jonge lambic style, quite tasty and fab that a traditional brewer has tried this.
On tap at Pub Royale. Pours cloudy tan. Flavor is simple and manageable sour. A very simple tasty, slightly salty sour. Not a whole lot of depth, but nice.

Cask, Peterborough Beer Festival 2015. Amber gold with a thin head. Woody, yeasty and tart with strawberries and jif lemon. Funky cheese with green apple. Vinegar with spritzy, woody, floral yeast. Clean on the palate and.. Its gone.
smells sharp and fruity, coppery colour with a white head, nice sour and fruity apples and maybe a bit of damson, bloody good!

Copper with white head. Aroma is funky, strawberry, dusty, earthy, like walking in to a cellar. Taste of green apple up front then a long earthy and slightly metallic flavour in the finish. Crisp and dry. Tastes a bit like a cider. Fucken English Lambic, must be kidding me..
From the tap oozed a heavy, hazy, copper brew. Tart with a sweet back beat. Silky smooth.
Tap @ Cap Ale Downtown. Glowing peachy amber with nice head that dissipated. Lemony aroma. Tart and funky. Nice.

Growler fill from The Wink. Hazed dark gold, head foams up and dies immediately, almost like a cider. Aroma is pleasantly horsey and tart apple. Flavor is a match, with a faint note of cheddar in the back. Really quite nice. Wish it was just the slightest touch drier on the front, but really good. Nice to try the microflora from another place.

On tap at Creekside Local Cantina for Tim McWhorters book release of "Blackened." Clear dark amber pour with a thin off-white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, tart fruit and apricot. Malty flavor with apricot sweetness before a tart fruit finish.
это пиво очень вкусно. я бы, конечно, рекомен& его всем. пожалуй& обратит& его. очень хорошо!
Cask at the pigs ear festival... Amber... Soft fruits funk nose... Soft tart fruits.. Sift funk.. Liggt dry funjybfruits.. Soft juicy fruits
Cider pour, nice off white head, if quickly receding. Tart, funky, fruity aroma, flavor is very tart and acidic, of vinegar, cherries and berries.
Pours a reddish copper. Very little head. Aroma of nice tart, sour red fruit. Taste is nicely sour and tart. Not as tart as say Hanssens, but really refreshing and great.

4th December 2014Pigs Ear. Cask. Almost clear gold beer, no head. Palate is light with a really nice fine crispness. Good condition. Nice mellow sourness, enough to tickle the taste buds. Zippy lemon and generic fruits. Light crisp finish. A very nicely joined up, unforced and approachable Lambic and a very nice suprise.

On tap at Local Cantina in Grandview. Orange gold pour with thin white head. Aroma of berry, vinegar, apple. Tastes of tart cherry, vinegar, oak, jammy funk. Moderate pucker. Pretty straightforward, but good at what it does.

Cask gravity at Pigs Ear 2014. Clear golden brown thin white head. Some lambic sourness on aroma some toffee. Very good. Nice lemony unblended lambuc style. Proper wild fermentation flavours no injected lactose that so many uk sours have. Really very impressive as an unblended lambic. Needs some refinement but good.

Backlog rating. Keg at The Rake, London. It pours a golden color with almost no head to speak of. Aroma is acidic and lemony, with notes of grass, lemon juice, citrus leaves, hay, funk and ripe apricots. Taste is medium sweet with tartness throughout and a clean dry acidic finish. Notes of lemon juice, funk, dust, grassy leaves, tangy salty berries. Light bodied with lively carbonation. Overall, very tasty for a British lambic
On tap at Capitol Beer & Tap Room. Pours Light amber with a nice beige head and a fruity aroma. There is a medium-bodied sour fruit flavor with a tart finish. Sure tastes like a traditional Lambic.

on draft that poured a clear medium orange with no head and light carbonation. aroma was acetic and grassy, flavor was full of fruit green apples and some citrus. medium sourness on the tongue with a mild tang. liked this one and first time with an unblended lambic...true crisp flavors from start to finish...and the finish was somewhat dry..overall very nice beer.
Surprised at some of the lackluster reviews on this one. Juicy with lots of fruit coming through. Nice sourness, not acetic at all. Clean and focused.

on tap @ Sergios / Louisville KY --- Nearly clear dark amber with a thin white head cover, smudges of lace. Taste is malt that turns beautifully sour on the swallow with hints of apple that drift through a long finish. Cleansing on the palate, as well as a good appetite awakener, a solid lambic.
Draft. Vinegar, green apple, and toffee malt aroma. Amber with small head. Sweet-tart green apple, light vinegar and caramel malt flavor. Nice balance. Pleasant.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2014 Tap: Hazy amber color with a bit of copper towards the center. Gray tinted foam fizzles out quickly. Aroma bursts with heavy acetic acid, balsamic vinegar, alcohol, wet & mildewy wood, & a hint of generic sour fruit skins... Stone fruit-ish. Theres a really strong flavor of whiskey, start to finish. Not sure why, as I doubt this was aged in any type of whiskey vessel? Underneath, I get some cherry skin, lemon, balsamic vinegar, lactic acid, & some funky popcorn kernel notes in the finish. Tastes like someone dropped a watered down shot of Jameson in to an underdeveloped lambic. Not the best. Too much alcohol (whiskey flavor) & vinegar.

A golden sour ale with a thin white head. In aroma, beautiful fruity malt with light Epsom salts, ground cherries, lemon juice, classic. In mouth, a nice sweet fruity malt with ground cherries, lemon, tart yet refreshing, well done. On tap at Farmhouse tap and Grill.

Generic stemmed tulip on draft at the Beveridge Place Pub in West Seattle. No head, almost still looking except some visible carbonation bubbles traveling up through the amber-gold body.  Clear but thick body.  Aroma bursts with sour cherry, a bit too much acetic vinegar, and a dusty maltiness. Unfortunately the bearable acetic becomes almost overpowering in the flavor.  Its all vinegar with a harsh sour finish.  Its not nail polish but acetic and harsh.  Could not finish half the glass (too much acetic makes the palate go blind) and ended up blending for fun.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Dont worry about the other ratings, this is real lambic, a taste to behold, the taste of real beer. Frick off those hoppy bastards, yeas, just a good over all example of what beer should be my friend. Darker than pale tis beer has a slight olfactory of sweet perfume, yummy. Titillating co2 from the start. Taste us just simply great, this beer rocks. Look, I like sour beer and this is it fer sure. Yummy all round. THis is all me. Very well done brewers from engly! Go get em my ancestors.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
[ Tap ][ 4oz ][ @Maxs ][ $3 ][ Mini Weizen-glass ][ 7/23/14 ]
Hazy tea-gold, fizzy white head. Dusty nose, moderate acetic raspberry and light lactic yogurt, brown sugar hints. Metallic profile, heavy carbonation throughout, thin green apple front palate, more acetic and sugar hints mid through the burning end, faintly seedy strawberry through the thin, finish, overly slick and syrupy with heavy sweetness.

Tap at Maxs. Pours clear dark gold with no head. Aroma is lactic grapes and crisp cracker malt and black walnut notes. Flavor is moderate lactic grapes, lemon zest, crisp malt and a dry finish. Light body and faint carbonation.
Draft. Pours honey gold white head. Nose/taste of pear alcohol, sour vinegar tartness and oak. Medium body.

On tap in a tulip. Pours hazy amber/brown with a small head. Aroma of sourness/tartness, some fruit characteristics, pale malts, and some light woody characteristics. Flavor the same with a nice blend of it all. Average texture. I dont really get the hate for this beer on this site, since I thought it was pretty good.

Location: Draft at Jake Melnicks, 5/27/14


Aroma: The aroma is of this one is pretty tart, plenty of vinegar, and some sour fruit

Appearance: Pours a murky reddish-orange color with a decent off-white head

Flavor: Flavor-wise, it has lots of sour fruity and tartness, vinegar, much like the nose

Palate: The body is medium, with an acidic/sulphur kind of feel, and a tart/sour finish

Overall Impression: 
I thought this was a nice attempt at the style, obviously it isnt a top of style beer, and its probably too vinegary for my palate, but it is probably a little better than its score on here.
Draft. Brown pour with tan head. Light tart aromas, hints of balsamic vinegars, sweetness. Flavors follow, very wild and lightly tart and sour, would like to see this age and or be blended.

Hazy caramel orange in color... Aroma of light citrus tartness, barely there... Flavor is intensely tart, citrus fruits, hard to pinpoint specifics on this, has a slight spiciness on the finish note present in other sours... Really good

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft at Rattle n Hum. Moderately funky and rustic, with some light rhubarb-like sweetness, moderate acidity, some grainy malty notes, and some lingering dusty funky notes. Pretty good.

Approx 10 oz draft pour at Mikkeller Bar in San Francisco, California. The pour is clear gold with a thin white head. The aroma is acetic sour, very strong, approaching vinegar. There is some fruit character as well, orange, berry, apples. The taste is mouth puckering sour, really shockingly so - its acetic vinegar, sharply so. As with the nose, after the sour settles in, there is apple cherry fruit, earth, and general funkiness. The palate is medium bodied, close to still carbonation and the earth funky sour finish. Pretty over the top, and not at all nuanced.
On tap at Pizza Plant Transit. Some sourness. Not a major leaguer but worth trying and ok drinkability.

Draft. Pours bright gold with minimal white head. Aroma is bright lemon, cherry, nail polish remover. Taste is punch-in-the-mouth lemon/sour cherry. Bright, crisp and delicious. That acetone smell/taste is prevalent but I dig it (whats up with that?). Clean finish on the palate. Yum.
Yellowish brown color with low carbonation and disappearing head. Very tart with flavors of cherry, peach, and grape.

Draft at Hopleaf, 4/19/14Bright orange with some softer banana-yellow hues in there and a wispy white head that is quick to recede to the edges. Clarity is fairly high while carbonation is only lightly perceptible.Some vegetal notes, as others point out, are notable in the nose, detracting somewhat, I guess, though there is healthy dose of lactic acid and plenty of "funk" to it mostly in the form of farm animal poop (sulphur). Lots of fruitiness with green apples, cherries and even a touch of citrus helping to lighten the mood a bit while the malt seems mostly attenuated from the nose. Medium to medium-high strength of aroma with no alcohol, thankfully and while you may wish for a more brett-laden nose, Im perfectly happy with this one.Lactic sourness washes over the palate, initially, as some malt sugars announce themselves as not being fully attenuated (though its far from sweet), lending a little bit of strength to the body. Incredibly low carbonation, though what is there is rather tight/engaging, helping to cast the sourness about while removing the sweetness. Lots of the fruitiness (esters) from the nose, with just a touch of rotting fruit (acetic) notes, though I found no where near the level that some others mention. Plenty of sulphur, lacto and just a hint of brett on the very end. No alcohol in the flavor either.Sure, this is no top notch lambic, but come on, the fact that Elgoods, what I can only see (from the database) as being a wholly mediocre brewery, produced this, is quite impressive. Certainly wouldnt run out of my way to drink it, but would be happy to drink again if it was one of the few sours on tap. Would love to know the story behind this beer.

At Calientes. Pours a clear reddish orange with a foamy white head. Aroma of vinegar, sour apple, blackberry. Taste is medium sour. Mostly acetic acid sour but not overpowering like Upton. I enjoyed this one.

Draft on tap at Northdown Cafe (Chicago, IL). Interesting find. Pours a hazy amber orange hue, a bit dulled but some decent fall glow in this light hits the edges and bottom. Frothy whitish head dissipates to skant ring that doesnt really lace at all atop. Aromas are a bit sour, lemony lactic elements meet a gentle funk, bready malts touch citrus, touches of orange and cobwebs, gentle vanilla meets touches of green apple, some stone fruit and yogurt. Initial is lighter end of the fold in body offering a bit less than the nose was preaching, a bit muddled as bready malts meet tart fruit, touches of citrus, gentle lactic acidity. Mellow bread and gentle dusty cobwebs taper into a sweeter fruity middle, touches of earth and bretty dryness kick a but more into the backend. A bit dry and earthy, as the sourness kicks up a bit more as we finish. Some gentle white wine, sour apple and lemon. A touch sweet in the middle but overall a serviceable offering. Nose seemed to offer promises of more but its not bad.
16oz draft pours orange with a white head. Aroma of fruit . Taste is tart cherries, apples and sour.

Draft to taster at Dutchs. Looks deent; a fairly transparent lambic orange with thin head that completely dissipates pretty quickly. Smells tart and lacto-ey with more vinegar than Id prefer. Tastes like it smells with a below average mouthfeel. This lambic sucks.

Draft at Dutchs as Coolship #1. Pours a hazy orange golden color with a small disappearing off white head. The aroma and flavor have a sweet/sour thing going on; sweet tart fruit, cherries on the nose with the flavor showing more sour character, acidity, wood, slight burn. I think it becomes assertive as it warms.

Ran out if work early to try this puppy at taproom 307. Pours flat clear copper. Nose is pickle brine and white grapes. Tastes of grape, pineapple, blackberry, quite lactic, maybe lemon. Quite sour and maybe mineral finish. You get that unblended feeling but a bit harsher with more odd Flavors mixed in.
Copper, with a thin ring of foam. Smells like blueberry, blackberry, and some lemony, citric acid aromas. Taste is sour and lightly fruity, with apple and pear and berry flavors. Very tasty...

Tap. Poured hazy orange copper color with an minimal frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with fair lacing. Moderate sour fruit and yeast aroma. Medium to abundant body with a dry texture and flat carbonation. Medium sour fruit flavor with a medium sour finish of moderated duration. This is a standout for style beer.
On tap at Barleys. Comes golden orange with a small white head. Aroma of tart fruit and yeast. Taste is tart cherries, apples, funk, and vinegar. Not a favorite of mine.

Draft at Neons. Pours a lightly clouded golden orange with almost no head. Aroma of sour apples, oak, vanilla, apricot, lemon-lime, and sweet dough. Flavor of sour grapes and apples, vanilla, oak, sourdough, tannins. Very funky and sour. Light-medium bodied, with a sweet and sour balance and moderate carbonation. Grew on me. Good sour.
Drought. Pours hazy orange with very small whitish foamy head, citrus aroma, sour grapefruit taste, low carbonation, long sour finish. A weird brew, tastes more like a fruit cocktail.

On tap at Neons. Labeled "Coolship #1 Aged Lambic". Pours a totally hazy burnt orange color. Very thin ring of white head. Good, bigger sour taste, very satisfying level of sour and funk. Darker color for an unblended lambic, a bit more of a darker, complex fruity malt character than Im used to from the very few unblended lambics Ive tried... Makes it interesting, though. Good oak, cherry, light vinous notes, good tannin. Light spiciness. Some vanilla up front in the nose, and nice mild funk. Medium to bigger body, lightly slick. Light carbonation. This was a nice, enjoyable, complex lambic. Satisfyingly sour, too. Bartender warned me "Its really sour..!". I replied, "Good." Its not the most utterly sour lambic Ive had, but definitely a nice level of sour... Id describe it as moderate to bigger sour, with a light to moderate sweetness, too.
From tap. Aroma is vinegar and cork. Tart cherries. Hints of honey. Attacks the tongue. Fairly flat. Enjoyable.

Draft at Clinton hall NYC. Pours a brick dark red color. No head.taste is slightly tart but not overwhelming. Pretty good

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft. Definitely some sourness nad tartness, here. Fruit notes, slight funk, bucyric acid.

On tap at Roscoes, pours a cloudy dark golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is highly vinegary, with loads of acidity and nothing resembling a true lambic. Flavour is very acidic, sharp and vinegary, nothing like an authentic lambic, though its quite unique and drinkable despite this. Very lacto-ish for a lambic. Not so good, but drinkable.

Draft at the Sunset Grille and Tap in Allston, MA. Pours a dark amber with a very thin head. Aromas of cherries, sour apples, souring yeasts, must, and grapes. The taste was more muddle than I like with this style. It had some of the noted tartness, but overall I thought it was mediocre. Somewhat tart apples, grapes and cherries. Not smooth, but rigid to drink. Light body and almost no carbonation. Finish is some tartness. Meh.
Pours amber with a slight haze and no head. Slight tart and grape juice aroma. Taste was acidic, but mellow; notes of grape juice sweetness.

Keg at The Rake. 9 months old. It pours cloudy deep orange-amber with no head. The nose is earthy, tangy, orange, creaminess, floral, wood and faint vanilla. The taste is tart, tangy, bitter-sweet, tangy apple, pear skin, sherbet, earth, restrained acidity, wood, wet leaf, orange, sour sweets, peach, granny smith apple and fruit salad. Dry, mouth-puckering finish. Medium body, low carbonation and soft mouth-feel. Very well-rounded and balanced. Pretty impressive stuff.

Keg at the Rake, 12/02/14.
Murky orange brown with no head.
Nose is tangy dark fruits, dank wood, bitter red grapes, light fruit balsams, citric tinged straw.
Taste comprises light acidic qualities, soured pineapple, dank wood, citric tinges, fruit balsams, musty pangs.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close.
Decent stuff if a little overly sweet.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: On keg at The Rake. Colour is rusty, cloudy orange/amber, no head. Nose is brown malt vinegar, touch of balsamic vinegar, apple tannins, tart vinegary, sharp acidic. On the taste its almost somewhere toward a Flemish sour because theres a lot of brown malt vinegar, and vinegar tartness, apple tannin, white apple when its turning brown, acidic tart, urine, some funky horse blanket in the taste. I prefer a cleaner crisper lambic, but this is young so its pretty raw.

Tap at The Rake. Pours a murky orangy brown with no head. Pleasant sourness in the aroma with a little lemon and very light custard. Light to medium body, mild fine carbonation. Lemon, sponge pudding, light custard, apricot. Very pleasant. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Keg at the rake London bridge. Murky onion skin coloured pour with no head. Aroma is mixed bag of sharp fruits like pineapple and granny smith apple and a touch of raspberry jam. Flavour is initially crab apple jam, slight sweet, raspberry. Light acid and some mustyness in the finish. Some citrus in the finish as well. Palate is medium sticky sweet. Prickly at the back of the throat. Decent stuff. Very approachable tartness.

Keg at the Rake - Borough Market, London. Pours murky, orange-good with almost no head. Lots of tangy citrus fruits on the nose, tangerine, hints of pine needles. Medium sweet flavor with rich, tart citrus character, mandarin orange, tangerine, lemon, Meyer lemon, melon, honeysuckle, moderate acidity. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Good sour bite to finish, more citric lemons and tangerines, some orange candies. Quite tasty and very drinkable.

Draught @ Alltech brews and food, Dublin. What a fascinating beer, brewed in England in one of the few breweries to have coolships knocking about. Pours a murky orange, no head. Sour, fruity, zesty nose. Sour pithy orange flavour. Slick mouthfeel, low carbonation, long fruity bitter finish. Some residual sweetness in the finish. Think this may be the first commercial batch of this, Cantillon have been at it a while longer, but very impressive.
